sections.html:
Zone 2 • Case Studies

Water Case Studies

Global Examples • One Measurement Language

People argue about "the best water" because they compare different waters with different metrics. This page solves that.

We use one universal comparison fingerprint (EC, ORP, pH, Turbidity) + context: source type, geology, treatment, and time.

Definition

Water case studies are standardized profiles that compare different sources using the same fingerprint (EC/TDS, ORP, pH, turbidity) plus source context and time-based drift.

The Source Categories

Natural Sources

  • Springs: Mountain, volcanic, limestone
  • Groundwater: Mineral-heavy wells
  • Surface: Rivers, lakes (variable turbidity)

Treated Sources

  • Municipal: Treatment + distribution effects
  • Filtered: Carbon, multi-stage
  • RO/Distilled: Low solids, container-sensitive
Comparison Framework

The 4-Parameter Interpretation Guide

1. EC/TDS

"How many charge carriers?" Not identity, not quality alone.

Read More

2. ORP

Redox context. Driven by oxygen, temp, and time.

Read More

3. pH

Buffer + gas context. Drifts with CO₂ exchange.

Read More

4. Turbidity

Particle load & settling behavior.

Read More

Natural

Notes: Geology dominates mineral identity. Bottling affects gases.

Surface

Practical: Creating a Case Study

The Kit

Glass jar, Thermometer, EC/TDS, ORP, pH meters.

The Rule

  • Measure at 0h, 2h, 24h.
  • Always log temperature and container type.
Get Kit Log Template

Join the Network

This library becomes a living engine with your data.

Citizen Science Hub Experiments Index Comparison Protocol

How to Read the Map (Warnings)

Rule 1: Patterns over Points

Don't compare single readings. Compare patterns over time.

Rule 2: Container Effects

Different sizes/materials distort comparisons.

Rule 3: Temperature

Temp shifts can mimic chemical effects.

Rule 4: Source Context

A spring is an ecosystem. A tap is a pipe network.

items.question: Why do we need case studies?
items.answer: To compare different waters with the same measurement language and reduce confusion.

items.question: What's the best baseline water for experiments?
items.answer: RO or distilled can be useful as a 'low solids baseline,' but storage effects matter. Use controlled containers.

items.question: Why does tap water drift after sitting?
items.answer: Gas exchange and distribution chemistry can change ORP/pH over time.

items.question: Can I submit water from anywhere?
items.answer: Yes—any location is useful if logged with the standard protocol.

items.question: What readings matter most?
items.answer: The whole fingerprint: EC/TDS + ORP + pH + turbidity, plus temperature and time.
